FacilityName: City of Muskogee Pollution Control Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Muskogee, Oklahoma operates a pollution control plant located within the city limits in the southeast portion of the city.  The plant uses chlorine to treat the city's wastewater for the city.  The wastewater treatment plant holds safety as its first priority, especially when it comes to chlorine.  The maximum inventory is twelve tons and the plant limits the maximum number of cylinders in use at any one time to three.
The worst case scenario for the City of Muskogee Pollution Control Plant is a 1-ton cylinder resulting in an estimated Level of Concern (LOC) of 5.9 miles using the National Safety Council's ALOHA mapping program.  The first alternate scenario represents the severing of a transfer hose (whip) from the cylinder to the header pipe.  This has an estimated LOC of 5.3 miles and a release of approximately 1,093 pounds.  This alternate is most likely to occur.  The second alternate scenario is a release representative of a culmination of both of the previous scenarios.  This could occur if a tank ruptured and other tanks were able, due to failure of controls, to flow back along the header pipe and out the broken transfer hose (whip).  This would result in the release of approximately 2,930 pounds of chlorine and result in a LOC footprint of 6 miles.
The City of Muskogee Pollution Control Plant follows a strict operation, safety and maintenance program to minimize the likelihood of an accident occurring at the facility.  Because of the strict implementation of the above-mentioned programs, this facility has not had a release within the last five years.
The City of Muskogee Pollution Control Plant holds training and refresher courses for the personnel at the facility regarding the chlorine system and its concerns and Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA).  However, if an accident occurred, the City of Muskogee Fire Department and Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) would be notified and would respond immediately.
The City of Muskogee Pol
lution Control Plant has no current plans to change the chlorine process in the foreseeable future.
